subject: PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: FujiFilm (4901 JT) is to purchase a Danish biopharmaceutical production unit from Biogen (BIIB) for an estimated USD 890mln
content:
JAPAN

FujiFilm (4901 JT) - Co. is to purchase a Danish biopharmaceutical production unit from Biogen (BIIB) for an estimated USD 890mln. (Nikkei)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Former Keidanren Japan Business Federation chief Sakakibara is said to be considered as candidate for Chairman role. (Newswires) - Co. confirms its Infiniti brand will exit Western Europe early next year and will end production of 2 models in UK this year. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co.-backed low-cost hotel provider Oyo is planning USD 800mln investment to raise presence in India and China. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Kia Motors (000270 KS) - Co. rolled out an upgraded K5 sedan in an effort to boost domestic sales. (Yonhap)

Other News - EU removed South Korea from its ‘grey list’ of countries subject to tax-related monitoring after its reformed rules were said to be inline with EU standards. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

USTR Lighthizer said getting a trade deal with China is a "big if" and that there are still major issues between US and China, although he hopes the countries are in the final weeks of having an agreement. Furthermore, Lighthizer said China's focus in trade negotiations is the removal of US tariffs which is now under debate and that he believes the US has to address market access issues in Japan in the coming trade talks. (Newswires)

Indian CPI Inflation (Feb) Y/Y 2.6% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.1%, Rev. 2.0%)

Indian Industrial Output (Jan) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.4%, Rev. 2.6%)

Indian Manufacturing Output (Jan) Y/Y 1.3% (Prev. 2.7%, Rev. 3.0%) 

UK/EU

UK PM May lost Brexit vote by 391 against vs. 242 for (149 vote margin). This was after the key findings from the AG’s address was that whilst the path to exit the backstop was clear and binding, and the likelihood of a EU/UK disagreement in the arbitration process was low, a unilateral right to exit the backstop was not achieved. PM May later said she is committed to holding other votes this week and that if the house votes for an extension, the government will seek to agree it with the EU. Elsewhere, a spokesperson said PM May has not discussed resigning which followed reports that some Tory lawmakers were said to be mulling approaching UK PM May in a delegation to ask her to resign. (Newswires/Twitter)

EU Council President Tusk spokesperson said it is difficult to see what more the EU can do without solution to the impasse in London, while the spokesperson added that the result of the vote has significantly increased likelihood of a no-deal Brexit and EU will decide unanimously on any request to delay Brexit. (Newswires)

Brexiteers are considering laying down a Malthouse Plan B amendment for the no-deal motion tomorrow, according to BI's Adam Payne citing Steve Baker. There were also separate reports that group of UK lawmakers to propose amendment for tomorrow's vote that the government should seek Article 50 extension until May 22 in order to prepare for a no-deal exit and will also state the government should offer mutual standstill agreements with EU for an agreed period ending by end-2021 at the latest. (Newswires/Twitter)

ERG Chief Rees-Mogg suggested the UK is heading for a no-deal Brexit without extension. (Newswires)

ECB Praet (Dovish) said negative ECB rates continue to be a powerful tool to reach price stability objective and that Europe is on route to reaching ECB's inflation target. (Newswires)

ECB is unlikely to decide on the final TLTRO conditions before June and policymakers will calibrate based on growth figures, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK GDP Estimate (Jan) M/M 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.4%) UK GDP Estimate (Jan) Y/Y 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.0%) UK Industrial Output (Jan) Y/Y -0.9% vs. Exp. -1.3% (Prev. -0.9%) UK Manufacturing Output (Jan) Y/Y -1.1% vs. Exp. -1.9% (Prev. -2.1%)

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories -2.6mln vs. Exp. +2.7mln (Prev. +7.3mln). (Newswires)

OPEC+ pact extension for H2 2019 may be made in April. (IFX)

UAE Energy Minister Al Mazrouei said OPEC+ deal output compliance is improving and that the UAE has curbed more output in February with compliance at 119% of target cut. (Newswires)

US EIA cut 2019 world oil demand growth forecast by 40k BPD to an increase of 1.45mln BPD Y/Y and cuts 2020 forecast by 20k BPD to a 1.46mln BPD YY increase. (Newswires)

US

USTR Lighthizer said working towards steel/aluminium solution for Canada and Mexico to eliminate tariffs on their products, as well as providing them with historical access to the US market and maintaining the benefits of the steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department opened an anti-dumping investigation on acetone imports from Singapore, South Korea, Spain, South Africa, Saudi Arabia and Belgium. (Newswires)

US CPI NSA (Feb) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.6%). (Newswires) 

US Core CPI (Feb) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.2%)

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) continued its sell-off on Tuesday as the list of countries grounding its 737 Max 8 jet countries grew larger; Southwest (LUV) and United Airlines (UAL), whose fleets are largely composed of the jet, both traded lower too. Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB) opened in the green after finding relief on the back of the EU dropping plans to introduce a digital tax on big tech. Tesla (TSLA) came under pressure following Morgan Stanley cutting delivery estimates. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) enjoyed some spicy gains on the launch of its new loyalty programme. HP Enterprise (HPE), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Monster Beverage (MNST) all suffered from downgrades at UBS, JPMorgan and BMO Capital respectively. SPX +0.30% at 2792, NDX +0.52% at 7201, DJI -0.38% at 25555.

The bid in Treasuries were particularly strong on Tuesday, despite equities trading higher. Further upside was seen in the complex after a solid 10-year auction, which stopped through the screens by 0.8bps. Analysts noted that real yields came in after a soft CPI report, with many suggesting that there isn't anything to suggest we are facing a spike higher in price pressures any time soon. Additionally, one trader noted that banks were said to be receiving in size, and corporate issuance was being swapped into floating rates, with the perception that yields will continue to fall. 10-year yields dropped beneath 2.60% - we haven't had a close beneath that level since early January. At settlement the cure bull-flattened. US T-note futures (M9) settled 7+ ticks higher at 122-28.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 12 March 2019: UK PM May deal voted down, again
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 12 March 2019: UK PM May deal voted down, again

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, treasuries up, crude flat/up.

* REAR VIEW: May’s Brexit deal voted against; Lighthizer cautious on China trade deal; US CPI comes in soft; ECB unlikely to provide details on TLTRO 3 before June; world vs. Boeing 737 Max 8

* AHEAD: EZ Industrial Production, US Durable Goods & PPI, US Construction Spending, Potential HoC Vote on no-deal, ECB's Mersch & Coeure Speaking, Supply from Italy, German and US, Earnings from: Adidas, E.ON, Prudential & Innogy

 

* BREXIT: UK PM May's Brexit deal was rejected by a margin of 149. The implication is that this makes a cliff-edged, no-deal Brexit less likely. On Wednesday, the UK is expected to vote on ruling out a no-deal Brexit, and following that, on Thursday, lawmakers will vote on extending the Article 50 process, which again, is expected. The knee-jerk reaction for the pound was positive, however, the post-vote gains were faded after reports that the remaining votes this week will be amendable, implying it is unclear at this stage what the final bill will look like. Additionally, it was reported by the Sunday Times that UK PM May will vote against leaving without a deal. Note, the situation remains fluid, and at pixel time, GBP remains volatile. There was also chatter that some Tory lawmakers are set to appraoch UK PM May in a delegation to ask her to resign.

* WHAT HAPPENS NEXT? POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?: As things stand, if MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit become possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imagines since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

* USTR TESTIMONY: US Trade Representative Lighthizer testified in front of the Senate Finance Committee today where he said there are still major issues between the US and China - with a deal being a “big if” - but hopes the countries are in the final weeks of having an agreement, although that if talks are not resolved then there will be no agreement. Lighthizer also said that President Trump will not agree to deal unless it is enforceable. Looking into progress of specific issues, the trade hardliner said that structural IP issues are being addressed “with precision” in talks; in addition the two nations have come very close to a currency agreement, and as it stands, China's currency agreement has real commitments and is enforceable. In regard to China’s requests, as expected, he said they are seeking the removal of tariffs, which “if that is a concession, that is something that is under debate.”

* US CPI: US February consumer prices was a touch softer than expected, with the headline at 1.5% YY, down from a prior and consensus 1.6%; the core measure fell to 2.1% YY from the consensus and prior 2.2%. "With headline CPI inflation edging down to a two-and-a-half-year low of 1.5% in February, and core inflation dropping to a four-month low of 2.1%, the Fed would appear to be justified in supporting the real economy by being patient and leaving interest rates on hold for a potentially extended period," Capital Economics said. The consultancy says that the headline was down on base effects, noting that MM growth came in 0.2%, driven by rises in food and energy prices; ex food and energy, the monthly rise was more muted at 0.1% MM. "Although the unemployment rate is back below 4% and average hourly earnings growth has accelerated to nearly 3.5%, there appears to be very little upward pressure on price inflation," CapEco says, explaining that this is partly due to a modest pick-up in productivity growth which has kept a lid on unit labour costs; additionally, the stronger USD has started to put downward pressure on imported goods prices. "If a US-China trade deal results in the removal of the tariffs introduced last year, that would introduce an additional source of disinflationary pressure," Capital Economics says, "in short, the Fed can safely ignore the minimal risk of a breakout in inflation above its 2% target."

* ECB SOURCES: ECB unlikely to decide on the final TLTRO conditions before June and policymakers will calibrate based on growth figures; according to sources. The committee proposed new TLTRO premium 25bps over the main refinancing rate, however governors pushed back as it was "too high". The piece added that the best TLTRO rate not seen going below zero, discussions still ongoing and growth weakness can change terms. The key goal of TLTRO is to reduce stock of loans to avoid a cliff edge effect in the future, and the article added that the ECB did not discuss tiered deposit only one governor expressed deep concern about negative rates.

* WTI (J9) SETTLED USD 0.08 HIGHER AT USD 56.87/BBL; BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.09 HIGHER AT USD 66.67. The crude complex traded choppy on Tuesday whilst the market digested various conflicting catalysts. On the one hand, prices were supported reports of Saudi production running a clear step below its 10.3mln BPD OPEC+ production target, and the further decline in Venezuelan oil production on the power outages of the past week. UAE’s Oil Minister said the OPEC+ deal compliance is improving, and Interfax reported that an extension of the deal for H2 2019 may be made in April. Crude was also helped by a weaker dollar after February CPI data showed some softness. On the other hand, global demand was again in concern: the EIA cut its world oil demand growth forecast for 2019 by 40k BPD to a 1.45mln BPD YY increase, as well as its 2020 forecast by 20k BPD to a 1.46mln BPD YY increase. In other news-flow it was reported that Nigeria’s Nembe Creek Trunk Line (150k BPD) resumed operations since being down from February 28th. The market is also looking ahead to this evenings API figures of US energy inventories, where crude stocks are again seen building at 2.7mln bbls, distillates drawing 1.9mln bbls, gasoline drawing 2.5mln bbls; Genscape forecasts the Cushing delivery hub building 671k bbls. Elsewhere, it was reported that OPEC has begun speaking to Wall Street in regard to NOPEC legislation, warning of US shale being the first to fall from such measures.

* SPX +0.30% at 2792, NDX +0.52% at 7201, DJI -0.38% at 25555. SECTORS: Energy +0.58%, Materials +0.35%, Industrials -0.90%, Cons Discretionary +0.23%, Cons Staples -0.02%, Healthcare +0.67%, Financials +0.19%, Tech +0.52%, Telecoms +0.56%, Utilities +0.62%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) continued its sell-off on Tuesday as the list of countries grounding its 737 Max 8 jet countries grew larger; Southwest (LUV) and United Airlines (UAL), whose fleets are largely composed of the jet, both traded lower too. Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB) opened in the green after finding relief on the back of the EU dropping plans to introduce a digital tax on big tech. Tesla (TSLA) came under pressure following Morgan Stanley cutting delivery estimates. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) enjoyed some spicy gains on the launch of its new loyalty programme. HP Enterprise (HPE), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Monster Beverage (MNST) all suffered from downgrades at UBS, JPMorgan and BMO Capital respectively.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 7+ TICKS HIGHER AT 122-28. The bid in Treasuries were particularly strong on Tuesday, despite equities trading higher. Further upside was seen in the complex after a solid 10-year auction, which stopped through the screens by 0.8bps. Analysts noted that real yields came in after a soft CPI report, with many suggesting that there isn't anything to suggest we are facing a spike higher in price pressures any time soon. Additionally, one trader noted that banks were said to be receiving in size, and corporate issuance was being swapped into floating rates, with the perception that yields will continue to fall. 10-year yields dropped beneath 2.60% - we haven't had a close beneath that level since early January. At settlement the cure bull-flattened.

* PREVIEW: 30-YEAR AUCTION (USD 16BLN, WEDNESDAY) 1300 EDT/1700 GMT): The previous 30-year auction in February stopped on the screws, with cover in-line with recent averages. The recent steepening of the curve might provide some support for the auction, analysts said. Foreign investors’ participation was higher (10% vs 4% at the January auction), and domestic participation slipped to 61% from the record high of 67%. “However, looking through the month-to-month volatility, domestic investors accounted for 63% over the past three months, versus 60% over the past year,” Barclays points out, adding that “On-the-run 30s are trading at a liquidity discount to old 30s (Nov 2048) in the forward space, which we think is justified, given that the latter is a CTD in deferred WN contracts.”

* GBP: UK PM May's Brexit deal was rejected by a margin of 149. The implication is that this makes a cliff-edged, no-deal Brexit less likely. On Wednesday, the UK is expected to vote on ruling out a no-deal Brexit, and following that, on Thursday, lawmakers will vote on extending the Article 50 process, which again, is expected. The knee-jerk reaction for the pound was positive, however, the post-vote gains were faded after reports that the remaining votes this week will be amendable, implying it is unclear at this stage what the final bill will look like. Additionally, it was reported by the Sunday Times that UK PM May will vote against leaving without a deal. Note, the situation remains fluid, and at pixel time, GBP remains volatile. There was also chatter that some Tory lawmakers are set to appraoch UK PM May in a delegation to ask her to resign.

* JPY: The haven bid saw some relief with constructive risk sentiment. There are, of course, domestic factors bubbling away that lend to some downside, too. A Bloomberg poll shows there is a growing expectation that the BOK will add more stimilus; BBG noted that in the poll, 37% of the 46 economists surveyed say te next policy move at BOJ towers will be an easing vs 18% who held that view in January.

* AUD: Overnight, data on the housing front disappointed (again), and the NAB February confidence print was not great, either. With that said, Aussie was trading firmer through European and US trading. Short-covering was cited (again), and some constructive risk sentiment. Analysts at WEstpac are now focussing on AUDJPY: "AUD has held its ground quite well against JPY in recent weeks given the aggressive move in interest rate markets to price in substantial risk of RBA rate cuts since the early Feb change of RBA policy bias and clear signs of slower growth in the Australian economy," and adds that "RBA rate cut talk should remain the key topic for AUD in coming weeks, though the focus is very much on Jul-Aug as the likely window for the first move and a cut is already fully priced by Sep-Oct." The Aussie bank notes that with AUD's commodity price support also driving large trade surpluses, JPY weakness may be the driver of the next sustained move on AUDJPY. "Spec positioning on USDJPY is helpfully balanced and market talk about looser monetary policy could pick up ahead of the BoJ's quarterly forecast release at the 24-25 Apr meeting," WEstpac says, "AUDJPY 80 looks like strong resistance in the short-term, but it should be broken, with scope for 81+ in April."

* SEK: Swedish inflation surprised to the downside for a second straight month with international travel responsible for most of the downside. "This is a technical effect explained by a change in the data source introduced in January," SEB explains, "the impact on the inflation rate is, however, likely to lower the inflation number until December this year." Taking international travel inflation out of the picture, food prices and some services prices were higher than expected, though goods prices (clothes) saw a downside surprise. "Clothes prices are volatile and the lower prices this month are likely to be reversed during the spring. Food prices are, however, likely to continue to rise leading to some upward pressure on the near-term forecast," SEB says. "The composition of price changes indicates that near term inflation pressures could be slightly larger than expected. Still, price pressures are lower than the Riksbank’s forecast, and today’s reading supports our forecast that the Riksbank will wait until next year before hiking again."

* AUD: Ahead of next week;s Norges Bank meeting, the February Regional Network Survey's output index fell fell slightly. "This points to quarterly mainland GDP growth of around 0.73% going forward, which is a little higher than the Norges Bank assumed in its December monetary policy report," Danske Bank said. Meanwhile, the aggregate output score for the last three months ticked higher, implying growth at around 0.72% QQ, highlighting that growth has been resilient at the beginning of the year, Danske noted. "All in all, a strong report confirming our projection of a March rate hike next week," Danske said, "at this stage, domestic factors suggest the front-end will remain little changed and that market pricing hence is too soft." The bank has previously recommended selling EUR/NOK via a 2M bearish risk reversal."

* BRL: Data today showed Brazilian IPCA inflation rising 0.4% MM, in line with expectations, and the YY rising by 3.9% vs 3.8% previously. The data was mainly driven by school fees and food prices, which offset the drag from declining transportation costs and clothing prices. "Tuition fees rose 3.5% month-to-month in February, reflecting the annual adjustment, but this was smaller than the 3.9% rise in February 2018 and the 5.0% jump in 2017," Pantheon Macroeconomics says, "food prices rose by 0.8%, in contrast to the 0.3% drop in February 2018, due to higher prices for food consumed at home." The consultancy says that overall, the trend in inflation should be stable over the next three months, as a lagged response to soft growth and still-high unemployment. "We see no immediate threats here, except some potential volatility in the FX market driven by news on progress with the fiscal reform agenda," but adds that "if reforms are approved over the second half of the year, as we expect, inflation will remain relatively tame, thanks to modest demand-related pressures, and the ample—albeit shrinking—output gap." Pantheon says that this will likely continue to lend support to the argument that the BCB will keep rates unchanged for the foreseeable future. More immediately, attention now moves on to Friday, when th government plans to auction 12 airports, followed by railroads and other ports later in the month. Some analysts note that a successful auction will bolster new President Bolsonaro's pro business credentials, supporting the BRL.

* CNY: There were some murmurings in the APAC time zone of a call between China Vice Premier Liu He and US Trade Rep Lighthizer, and although now real detail came of the report, it was enough to inspire a 'US/China trade talks optimism' response. Both apparently discussed the content of the trade agreement, and agreed on further talks. CNK noted that there was some injection of volatility into the USDCNY, as a result, noting that over the past few weeks, the currency pair had remained fairly stable, with realised volatility remaining at subdued levels. "However, as there is little concrete information for the time being, volatility is unlikely to sustain and market will probably return to the mute mode soon," Commerzbank said.

The bank has previously recommended selling EUR/NOK via a 2M bearish risk reversal."

* BRL: Data today showed Brazilian IPCA inflation rising 0.4% MM, in line with expectations, and the YY rising by 3.9% vs 3.8% previously. The data was mainly driven by school fees and food prices, which offset the drag from declining transportation costs and clothing prices. "Tuition fees rose 3.5% month-to-month in February, reflecting the annual adjustment, but this was smaller than the 3.9% rise in February 2018 and the 5.0% jump in 2017," Pantheon Macroeconomics says, "food prices rose by 0.8%, in contrast to the 0.3% drop in February 2018, due to higher prices for food consumed at home." The consultancy says that overall, the trend in inflation should be stable over the next three months, as a lagged response to soft growth and still-high unemployment. "We see no immediate threats here, except some potential volatility in the FX market driven by news on progress with the fiscal reform agenda," but adds that "if reforms are approved over the second half of the year, as we expect, inflation will remain relatively tame, thanks to modest demand-related pressures, and the ample—albeit shrinking—output gap." Pantheon says that this will likely continue to lend support to the argument that the BCB will keep rates unchanged for the foreseeable future. More immediately, attention now moves on to Friday, when th government plans to auction 12 airports, followed by railroads and other ports later in the month. Some analysts note that a successful auction will bolster new President Bolsonaro's pro business credentials, supporting the BRL.

* CNY: There were some murmurings in the APAC time zone of a call between China Vice Premier Liu He and US Trade Rep Lighthizer, and although now real detail came of the report, it was enough to inspire a 'US/China trade talks optimism' response. Both apparently discussed the content of the trade agreement, and agreed on further talks. CNK noted that there was some injection of volatility into the USDCNY, as a result, noting that over the past few weeks, the currency pair had remained fairly stable, with realised volatility remaining at subdued levels. "However, as there is little concrete information for the time being, volatility is unlikely to sustain and market will probably return to the mute mode soon," Commerzbank said.

subject: Brexit - post-vote analysis; this week's votes will be amendable
content:
• UK PM May's Brexit deal was rejected by a margin of 149. The implication is that this makes a cliff-edged, no-deal Brexit less likely. On Wednesday, the UK is expected to vote on ruling out a no-deal Brexit, and following that, on Thursday, lawmakers will vote on extending the Article 50 process, which again, is expected. The knee-jerk reaction for the pound was positive, however, the post-vote gains were faded after reports that the remaining votes this week will be amendable, implying it is unclear at this stage what the final bill will look like. Additionally, it was reported by the Sunday Times that UK PM May will vote against leaving without a deal. Note, the situation remains fluid, and at pixel time, GBP remains volatile. There was also chatter that some Tory lawmakers are set to appraoch UK PM May in a delegation to ask her to resign. 
  • WHAT HAPPENS NEXT? POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?: As things stand, if MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit become possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imagines since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

BREXIT - Situation report ahead of Meaningful Votes
content:
* VOTE TIME: Expected to begin at around 1900 GMT (1500 EDT, 2000 CET).

* AMENDMENTS: There are no ammendments tabled, and as such, it will be a 'clean' vote on May's Brexit plan.

* VOTING MATHS: There are 650 members of the UK House of Commons, seven Sinn Fein MPs do not vote, four speakers do not vote, and four MPs who count the votes do not vote themselves. PM May needs 318 votes to pass her deal, assuming all lawmakers (who are able to) vote, including: 10 DUP votes, up to 65 ERG votes (from a total of 110), up to 40 Labour leave votes, and 4 Independent votes.

* VOTE MARGIN: May's Brexit bill was rejected overwhelmingly in January, by a margin of 230 votes (432 against vs 202 in favour). One theory is that if the margin of defeat is small, it may give May scope to make changes after the 21 March EU Summit, so the deal could be voted on again. However, ITV's political editor suggested that the vote would be lost by more than 100, leaving little scope for May to introduce a third meaningful vote. Sky News analysis suggests UK PM May will lose tonight's vote by more than 100 votes (projects 345 to vote against deal, 220 will vote for deal, 72 unknown).

* AG COX: UK AG Cox noted thta while the path to exit the backstop is clear and binding, and the likelihood of a EU/UK disagreement in the arbitration process is low, and a unilateral right to exit the backstop was not achieved. NOTE: a unilateral right to leave was a key red-line for the ERG and DUP, the likely king-makers in the upcoming meaningful vote. The ERG and DUP have both therefore said that they will not back the deal; the DUP will directly vote against, but some members of the ERG may abstain from the vote (the latter is likely to be more beneficial to UK PM May).

* CHANCES OF PASSING TODAY: Betting markets price in defeat for PM May. The implied probability of her deal passing fell to around 11% (vs 25-30% before the AG's opinion was published. Accordingly, many desks say the base case is still for the deal to be rejected on Tuesday, a no-deal Brexit ruled out on Wednesday, and lawmakers will vote for the Article 50 process to be extended on Thursday.

* GBP SCENARIO 1: Meaningful Vote fails (Tue)/no-deal blocked (Wed/Thu)/vote to extend A50 passes (Wed/Thu) (likely). Barclays says initial GBP reaction would be negative. Focus will then shift to 21 March summit, where any signs of a longer extension could lead to a rally.

* GBP SCENARIO 2: Meaningful Vote passes (somewhat likely). Barclays says it could open the door for new post-referendum highs.

* GBP SCENARIO 3: All votes fail (unlikely). Barclays sees GBP real effective exchange rate -2.5% as markets price higher probability of no-deal Brexit. Focus then shifts to 21 March summit where GBP will be almost entirely sensitive to Brexit newsflow.

* GBP SCENARIO 4: meaningful vote fails/MPs vote for no-deal (highly unlikely): Barclays says GBP REER -5%.

* WHAT HAPPENS NEXT? POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?: If MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit become possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imagines since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

Daily FX Wrap: another roller-coaster ride for Sterling, and meaningful vote still to come
content:
GBP

The Pound has been pushed from pillar to post yet again, with Cable and Eur/Gbp very volatile between 1.3290-1.3005 and 0.8655-0.8475 respectively on unfolding Brexit news, views and reports ahead of the 2nd Parliamentary vote on UK PM May’s deal that was rejected by an overwhelming 230 vote majority last time. Sterling kicked off Tuesday’s session in fine fettle following a last minute breakthrough in Strasbourg on the Irish backstop, but the reaction to legally binding assurances from the EU designed to allay fears about the ‘temporary’ or contingency arrangement was mixed, with many sceptics waiting for the thoughts of Attorney General Cox before deciding which way to sway. Indeed, the ERG and DUP, seen as swing voters, indicated that his considered opinion would impact their decisions, even though the former already received negative legal advice from an independent counsel. In the event, Cox deemed that there is no change in the legal risks of Britain getting trapped in the backstop given no unilateral recourse, and even though there has been clear clarification via a binding reinforcement of the UK’s legal rights. Nevertheless, highlighting substantive changes to the original WA and Political Declaration that make it easier for the UK to terminate the arrangement via arbitration the AG urged MPs to vote for the revised deal on political vs legal grounds. However, the DUP and ERG have subsequently signalled a thumbs down vs other individuals that seem inclined to back the deal this time round even if the motive is due to a no deal being the worse of 2 evils.  Cable is currently circa 1.3125 and the cross around 0.8585. Note, the ERG have set a time of 18.00GMT to make a final decision according to latest reports.

 

NZD/AUD 

The Kiwi has extended recovery gains vs the Usd through 0.6850 to 0.6870, partly on the back of another post-US data Greenback decline (DXY towards the base of a 97.286-96.900 range) and amidst latest US-Chinese trade commentary courtesy of USTR Lighthizer suggesting the 2 sides are close to a deal on FX. Aud/Usd also grinding higher and not far from 0.7100 at one stage on the same bullish combination, the Aussie hampered again by cross-winds as Aud/Nzd edges down towards 1.0300.

CHF/EUR

The Franc and single currency are benefiting from the Dollar’s demise to a degree as well, with Usd/Chf retreating further from 1.0100+ to just under 1.0070 and Eur/Usd firm within a 1.1245-90 band, but not really looking likely to test 1.1300 resistance or trigger expiry options at the big figure (1 bn). Note, no real reaction to ECB source of horse of the mouth comments from Praet that in truth did not add to the policy outlook or guidance offered last Thursday.

CAD/JPY

The Loonie has continued to outperform, or rather rebound firmly vs its US counterpart post-conflicting February jobs data and is now more comfortably back over 1.3400, while Usd/Jpy remains rangebound between 111.10-45m and mostly anchored to the bottom, though not close enough to seriously stir any interest emanating from a 1.1 bn option expiry at the 111.00 strike.

content:
THIS WEEK’S NET TREASURY SUPPLY USD 54BLN: The US Treasury will auction USD 78bln of new 3s, 10s re-opening, 30s re-opening; with USD 24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 54bln. No Fed add-ons.

RECENT PERFORMANCE: The uncertain outlook, risk asset jitters, and the prospect of no Fed hikes on the horizon has supported front-end of the Treasury curve recently; the market prices no hikes this year, with pricing tilting towards cuts in 2020. TD Securities expects this week’s auctions to go well given their expectation for no further coupon auction size increases ahead, and the fact that rates have remained relatively stable.

10-YEAR AUCTION (USD 24bln, Tuesday 1300 EDT/1700 GMT): The previous 10-year auction was weak, with cover matching a 12-month low, combined with a tail size at a 12-month high, with the latter largely a result of investment fund participation slipping. And the recent richening of the 10-year may keep investors side-lined; Barclays notes that on-the-runs are trading more special than older 10s when compared with previous auction cycles, and the bank argues that that suggests a build-up of a short base as the auction sets up. Barclays says it continues to maintain its recommendation to fade the liquidity premium in on-the-runs (the Feb 2029) vs. older 10s (the Aug 2028); “OnTR10s have cheapened 0.5bp in forward space. However, they still appear somewhat rich on the curve, especially if they do not end up trading as special as priced in the repo market.” Six auction averages: High-yield 2.954%, tail -0.2bps, cover 2.45x, dealers 25.8%, directs 10.6%, indirects 63.6%.

subject: BREXIT ANALYSIS AHEAD OF TODAY’S MEANINGFUL VOTE - ROLLING THREAD
content:
*PARLIAMENTARY ARITHMETIC

OVERVIEW - There are 650 members of the UK House of Commons, 7 Sinn Fein MPs do not vote, 4 speakers do not vote, and 4 MPs who count the votes do not vote themselves.

BREAKDOWN – PM May needs 318 votes to pass her deal, assuming all lawmakers (who are able to) vote, including:

  • The vote of 10 DUP votes
  • Up to 65 ERG votes (from a total of 110)
  • Up to 40 Labour leave votes
  • 4 Independent votes

 

*TODAY’S TIMETABLE [GMT]

  • From 09:00 – ERG independent legal opinion
  • 09:30 - Cabinet will be meeting
  • 11:15 - UK Brexit Secretary at the Brexit select Committee
  • Before 11:30 - Attorney General Cox's legal advice
  • 11:30 - Parliamentary Party to meet
  • 11:30 - 1922 Committee meeting
  • 12:30 - UK AG Cox will address the House of Commons
  • 13:00 - UK PM May opens the Meaningful Vote debate
  • 1800 - ERG meets to decide how to vote
  • 19:00 - Meaningful Vote starts

 

*RECENT RHETORIC

Attorney General Cox

  • "The legal risk remains unchanged that if through no such demonstrable failure of either party, but simply because of intractable differences, that situation does arise, the United Kingdom would have, at least while the fundamental circumstances remained the same, no internationally lawful means of exiting the Protocol’s arrangements, save by agreement"
  • UK PM May has made legally binding changes with the EU, UK not reaching a deal is highly unlikely
  • The key findings from the AG’s address was that whilst the path to exit the backstop is clear and binding, and the likelihood of a EU/UK disagreement in the arbitration process is low, a unilateral right to exit the backstop was not achieved. This is of particular importance, as whilst the AG continually tried to eschew the values of the renegotiated path to a backstop exit, a unilateral right to leave is a key red-line for the ERG and DUP, the likely king-makers in the upcoming meaningful vote.
  • This was confirmed throughout the questions portion wherein the star chamber of the ERG stated that they would not support UK PM May’s deal, whilst the DUP also did not seem convinced by the assurances offered. As such the balance remains tiled toward a failure in today's meaningful vote (ITV’s Peston suggests by well over 100 votes) despite UK PM May’s intended satiation of concerns prior to the HoC questions. This, however, does not eliminate the chances of UK PM May’s deal passing at some point, as a smaller losing margin keeps the idea of a 3rd meaningful vote alive (prev. 230 vote loss).

ERG

  • Jacob Reese Mogg noted that it is too early to say if the deal is enough but is a move in the right direction. Mogg also said he will focus on whether the unilateral declaration is genuinely unilateral. He is not sure if the EU promises are a “major change”
  • Steve Baker suggested the agreement falls short of what was expected
  • Another member stated that they will vote for PM May’s deal if the DUP Party supports it
  • New assurances do not meet tests for allowing the UK to override backstop set by ERG; according to top lawyers. Their Summary: 'In our opinion these measures:'    do not allow the UK to terminate the backstop in the event that negotiations over its future relationship with the EU cannot be brought to a satisfactory conclusion  do not provide the UK with a right to terminate the backstop at a time of its choosing, or indeed at any time, without the agreement of the EU
  • ERG are said to be split on how to respond to AG Cox's legal advice; according to BBC's Assistant Political Editor Smith

DUP

  • DUP source says it is unlikely DUP can back PM May's deal following AG Cox legal advice
  • DUP’s Wilson said PM May’s deal seems to fall short on what was promised, but will give due diligence on what has been said

Labour Party

  • Leader Corbyn noted that PM May’s agreement does not contain changes the Premier promised Parliament

Irish PM Varadkar

  • The agreements outcome is positive, hopes it will be endorsed by parliament and added the instrument does not undermine the backstop or applications

European Commission President Juncker

  • European Commission President Juncker told reporters that the legal add-on to the Brexit deal which stresses the temporary nature of the backstop, complements the withdrawal agreement without reopening it. Juncker also warned if her deal is voted down, there was “no third chance”

 

*SPREAD BETTORS

Ladbrokes' latest Meaningful Vote odds suggests about a 11% (Prev. 26%) chance the deal goes through today after AG Cox's legal advice

Sporting Index notes UK PM May is set to lose tonight's vote by 88 votes

 

*POSSIBLE SCENARIOS

MAY UNDER PRESSURE TO QUIT: May could yet secure the support of Brexiteers in her own party if she pledged to step down by June so that a new Prime Minister can lead the next round of negotiations with the EU, the Sunday Times said. One aide was said to have predicted that if Labour tabled another motion of no confidence in the Government, Tories might vote for it to bring May down.

THIS WEEK'S VOTES: To avoid humiliation, plans are reportedly being drawn-up to offer lawmakers the chance to vote on a motion that would outline the deal it would like, in order to show the EU what terms could be acceptable to Parliament. There is also a possibility that if the Meaningful Vote is rejected on Tuesday, planned votes on whether to rule out a no-deal Brexit and whether to extend Article 50 could be scrapped so May can attempt once more to try and secure concessions from the EU at the 21 March EU summit, The Times added.

  • GBP SCENARIO 1: Meaningful Vote fails (Tue)/no-deal blocked (Wed/Thu)/vote to extend A50 passes (Wed/Thu) (likely). Barclays says initial GBP reaction would be negative. Focus will then shift to 21 March summit, where any signs of a longer extension could lead to a rally.
  • GBP SCENARIO 2: Meaningful Vote passes (somewhat likely). Barclays says it could open the door for new post-referendum highs.
  • GBP SCENARIO 3: All votes fail (unlikely). Barclays sees GBP real effective exchange rate -2.5% as markets price higher probability of no-deal Brexit. Focus then shifts to 21 March summit where GBP will be almost entirely sensitive to Brexit newsflow.
  • GBP SCENARIO 4: meaningful vote fails/MPs vote for no-deal (highly unlikely): Barclays says GBP REER -5%.

 

POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?: If MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit become possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imagines since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

NORWAY STYLE: Meanwhile cross-party pro-EU lawmakers are said to be drawing up a new Brexit political declaration that commits the UK to a Norway style relationship with the EU, which could be tabled if May loses Tuesday's vote. And on the government side, Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly preparing a GBP 20bln 'bribe' in his budget, if May's deal is carried on Tuesday; the Chancellor had previously warned of a return to austerity if May's plans are rejected.

NAMES IN THE FRAME TO REPLACE MAY: The four leading names to succeed May: current Foreign Minister Jeremy Hunt, current Home Secretary Sajid Javid, former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, and former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.

subject: UK AG ADDRESS SUMMARY: Cox fails to satiate ERG and DUP
content:
The key findings from the AG’s address was that whilst the path to exit the backstop is clear and binding, and the likelihood of a EU/UK disagreement in the arbitration process is low, a unilateral right to exit the backstop was not achieved. This is of particular importance, as whilst the AG continually tried to eschew the values of the renegotiated path to a backstop exit, a unilateral right to leave is a key red-line for the ERG and DUP, the likely king-makers in the upcoming meaningful vote.

This was confirmed throughout the questions portion wherein the star chamber of the ERG stated that they would not support UK PM May’s deal, whilst the DUP also did not seem convinced by the assurances offered. As such the balance remains tiled toward a failure in todays meaningful vote (ITV’s Peston suggests by well over 100 votes) despite UK PM May’s intended satiation of concerns prior to the HoC questions. This, however, does not eliminate the chances of UK PM May’s deal passing at some point, as a smaller losing margin keeps the idea of a 3rd meaningful vote alive (prev. 230 vote loss).

subject: Nomura quants say its equity market sentiment index for US stocks has bottomed, and is improving slightly
content:
• "A short-covering flow in response to US retail sales numbers may have triggered some investors who were waiting for a 'buy on-dips' opportunity to follow the market," Nomura says, "for example, global macro HFs seemed to have taken profits on part of their short US equity positions, and equity long/short HFs also appear to have slightly increased their equity exposure"
  • With that said, the bank notes that aggregate risk-appetite of overall hedge fund remains subdued. "The US economic surprise index recovered to -31 points yesterday but remains lacklustre. In addition, we are cautious over the feasibility of a potential US-China trade deal."
  • "Since the US stock market is still experiencing a period of a needed consolidation, we might not read too much about the future scenarios into intraday market spikes or valleys led by changes in supply-demand conditions."
  • "All US major stock indices rebounded, while CTAs have not turned to 'buying-mode' so far," Nomura notes, "with the exception of algo-investors, which follow very short-term momentum like 5-day trends (like 'swing traders'), more common CTAs are more likely to execute profit taking at favorable price conditions."
  • Nomura say, however, that the remaining room for CTAs' to unwind their existing positions has greatly decreased. "Nomura estimates that over 80% of existing long positions on Russell2000 futures and over 60% on S&P500 futures has already been unwound by CTAs, and so systematic selling pressure already steadily diminishing," and adds that "as long as non-algo (i.e.,human) bearish investors do not re-accelerate their selling of US stocks over thenext week, most CTAs will complete their unwinding process, as suggested by theirpast positioning patterns," and in addition, "if the S&P500 maintains upward momentum at that time, the possibility will emerge that CTAs resume building fresh long positions."

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region took impetus from the M&A inspired tech-led rally on Wall St and with sentiment also underpinned on Brexit related optimism after UK PM May’s last-ditch effort to reach an agreement with the EU resulted in legally binding changes that is said to strengthen and improve the withdrawal agreement. ASX 200 (U/C) was led higher by the energy sector following recent strength in oil prices but with gains eventually pared by weakness in gold miners and financials, while the Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) outperformed with the JPY-risk dynamic in full swing. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) conformed to the heightened risk appetite and tech-kindled momentum, while China’s tax commissioner reiterated to enact significant tax cuts and there were also reports that top US and China trade negotiation officials discussed key issues and set the next steps in working arrangements over the phone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially subdued with demand sapped as focus was centred on riskier assets and with participants tentative ahead of a 5yr JGB auction, although prices then found mild support on return from the lunch break and after the auction results printed relatively inline with the previous. 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7128 (Prev. 6.7202)

 

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which they discussed key issues regarding ongoing trade talks and set the next steps in working arrangements. (Xinhua)

US

US Senior Treasury Official says what we have seen of the most recent French digital tax proposals could be 'highly discriminatory' against US business, & various parts of US government are studying whether this would right to react under trade agreements. (Newswires)

UK/EU

*PLEASE SEE THE HEADLINE FEED FOR A ROLLING BREXIT ANALYSIS POST AHEAD OF THE MEANINGFUL VOTE. 

UK PM May secured legally binding changes that strengthen and improve the withdrawal agreement, according to UK cabinet office minister Lidington who added that the whole UK cabinet approves of Brexit deal improvements. Lidington announced to lay a joint legally binding instrument and joint statement in parliament which provides confirmation EU cannot try to trap the UK in the backstop and if EU were to act with that intention, the UK could use it as basis for formal dispute through independent arbitration, while the joint statement said EU and UK commit to finding alternative arrangements to the backstop by 2020. However, PM May did not get the power to unilaterally exit the backstop, nor did she get a time limit placed on it. (Newswires)

European Commission President Juncker told reporters that the legal add-on to the Brexit deal which stresses the temporary nature of the backstop, complements the withdrawal agreement without reopening it. Juncker also warned if her deal is voted down, there was “no third chance”. Juncker said the EU wants the UK to exit an orderly way and we have a deal which does that. Juncker also commented there will be no new negotiations on Brexit and that it is this deal or Brexit may not happen at all, while he added that the UK must leave by May 23rd or hold elections for EU lawmakers. (Newswires/Guardian)

UK PM May said the UK will make a unilateral declaration that there will be nothing to stop UK from leaving backstop if talks break down and that we have secured what parliament has asked for regarding the backstop, while PM May added she stands by what Brexit deal achieves for Britain and that it sets us on course towards a good future relationship with the EU. Furthermore, the Times reported that PM May is understood to have discussed the possibility of extending Article 50 with EU’s Juncker. (Newswires/Times)

ERG's Rees Mogg said it was too early to say if this is enough but it’s a move in right direction, while ERG's Baker suggested it was not the first time the UK government has had to put a very good gloss on something which falls short of what was expected. Elsewhere, UK MP Collins said he will be voting against the government's motion on EU withdrawal and the DUP said it will study the detail of the latest EU-UK agreement, while UK opposition Labour Party Leader Corbyn said PM May's negotiations have failed and agreement with EU does not contain changes PM May promised parliament. (Newswires/BBC)

BBC Newsnight political editor tweeted 'Leading Brexiteer tells me: PM’s agreement with EU tonight just about looks OK. All down to Geoffrey Cox. If can provide robust legal advice that the UK can get out of the NI backstop, then this should go through'. (Twitter)

EU is said to be preparing for a delay to Brexit of at least a year, according to senior officials. (Times)

Irish PM Varadkar says the agreements outcome is positive, hopes it will be endorsed by parliament; adds the instrument does not undermine the backstop or applications. (Newswires)

Government Ministers seem wary regarding the idea of Attorney General Cox answering questions on his legal advice; BBC's Smith. (Twitter) Cabinet sources concerned that Attorney General Cox's advice will not be strong enough to win over the DUP/ERG; Times Coates.

Attorney Gernal Cox to make his statement on the legal opinion at 12:30 GMT, if there are no UQ this should begin at around 12:35; Parly. (Twitter)

New assurances do not meet tests for allowing the UK to override backstop set by ERG; according to top lawyers. (Guardian)

- do not allow the UK to terminate the backstop in the event that negotiations over its future relationship with the EU cannot be brought to a satisfactory conclusion

- do not provide the UK with a right to terminate the backstop at a time of its choosing, or indeed at any time, without the agreement of the EU

 

UK PM May's pitch to MPs said to say that the new deal "may not be everyone's perfect vision of Brexit - but we have won some important legally-binding changes, the unilateral decleration means there is ‘nothing to prevent’ the UK breaking off backstop"; according to Telegraph's Swinford. (Twitter)

 

A Parliamentary party meeting and a 1922 committee meeting are reportedly scheduled for 11:30 GMT. (Newswires)

EU27 ambassadors will meet at 09:00 tomorrow in Brussels, to deal with the meaningful vote fall out; FT Brussels Correspondent. (Twitter)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Jan) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.4%)

- UK GDP Estimate YY (Jan) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.0%)

- UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Jan) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)

 

EQUITIES

European equities are somewhat mixed having waned off opening highs [Euro Stoxx 50 Unch] following a relatively upbeat Asia-Pac session. Sector wise, energy stocks lag their peers alongside telecom names, whilst consumer discretionary outperforms. FTSE 100 (Unch) has been fluctuating with the Pound ahead of tonight’s Brexit Meaningful Vote (analysis available on the headline feed).UK banks are faring well with RBS (+3.0%), Lloyds Group (+2.7%) and Barclays (+1.6%) shares all higher on the latest Brexit developments where PM May secured “legally binding” assurances on the NI backstop. Upside in UK homebuilders [Persimmon +3.9%, Taylor Wimpey +2.7%] are also attributed to Brexit progress. Elsewhere, German Union Verdi has disapproved the proposed merger between Deutsche Bank (-1.5%) and Commerzbank (-1.2%), although share prices were little moved as the news hit the wires. Volkswagen (-0.5%) reported their final numbers which were largely in-line with the prelim report. Finally, State-side, Boeing (-2.0%) shares resumed its decline after Australia became the latest country to ground the Boeing 737 Max 8.

FX

GBP - Some volatility around the raft of UK data that was mostly better than expected, but ultimately it’s all about the looming Meaningful Vote after PM May managed to secure last minute legally binding assurances to the Irish backstop. Sterling remains elevated across the board, though some way off best levels as Cable pivots 1.3200 vs almost 1.3290 at one stage and Eur/Gbp rebounds from circa 0.8475 lows towards 0.8550 awaiting several potentially key and game-changing events before the debate starts in Parliament and the ballot begins from 19.00GMT. In terms of the aforementioned major factors that could have a bearing on the outcome, the Attorney General’s verdict on the addendums to the WA appear paramount and are expected before 11.30GMT when the ERG is scheduled to meet and formulate opinions. On that note, independent legal advice for the Group concludes that the assurances still fall short of providing the UK with a get out from the contingency arrangement, but the DUP decision could sway the ERG’s final judgement.

NZD/CHF/EUR/AUD - All firmer vs the Greenback that remains soft in wake of Monday’s mixed US retail sales release and due to Sterling’s extended recovery from sub-1.3000 lows, as the DXY straddled 97.000. The Kiwi is hovering just below 0.6850 and Franc is back above 1.0100, while the single currency has consolidated its comeback from post-ECB levels under 1.1200 to trade nearer the top of a 1.1245-90 range. Note, several big option expiries in Eur/Usd are close enough to influence trade into today’s NY cut, with 1.4 bn at 1.1250, 2.2 bn at 1.1225 and 1.9 bn at 1.1200 vs 1 bn at 1.1300. The Aussie has also benefited from a general improvement in risk sentiment within 0.7058-80 parameters, but still lagging its NZ peer as the Aud/Nzd cross remains capped ahead of 1.0350.

SEK/NOK - Mixed fortunes for the Scandi Crowns as softer than forecast (overall) Swedish inflation data contrasts with recent Norwegian CPI and the Nok also derives momentum from firm oil prices along with an upbeat Norges Bank regional survey. Hence, Eur/Sek sits around 10.5700 vs Eur/Nok circa 9.7350, +0.15% and -0.15% on the day respectively.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts continue to lead the way, and have rebounded quite sharply from worst levels as the countdown to major events in UK Parliament gets down to the wire. The 10 year UK benchmark is still around ½ point below Monday’s Liffe close but 40+ ticks above the low and Bunds have reduced their arrears to just 3 ticks vs 61 ticks at the 132.92 Eurex base. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are marginally softer and the curve a tad steeper ahead of US CPI, a speech from Fed’s Brainard and the 2nd slug of this week’s supply in the form of Usd24 bn 10 year notes.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.9%) and Brent (+0.9%) futures continue edging higher on the back of heightened risk appetite wherein the former extended gains above USD 57.00/bbl whilst the latter gained a firmer footing above USD 67.00/bbl. Traders will be eyeing tonight’s release of API crude inventories following last-week’s much wider-than-expected build in stocks.

Elsewhere, gold (+0.3%) posts marginal gains, aided by a mild pullback in the Greenback, copper (+1.4%) on the hand outperformed on the firmer risk sentiment.

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo that the oil market rebalancing continues to be a work in progress and supply adjustments will continue this year. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to withdraw all remaining diplomatic staff from Venezuela this week. (Newswires)

India's government has warned companies to stop purchasing Venezuelan oil or face undisclosed consequences, according to Petroleum Secretary Kutty who added that large companies have already stopped accepting Venezuelan crude. (Newswires)

Gilts gap down in line with Short Sterling futures after backstop ‘breakthrough’
content: In line with a marked upturn in risk sentiment, largely due to latest (11th hour) Brexit developments, UK debt and STIR contracts have resumed Liffe on the backfoot, and after a brief period of consolidation and loss paring, are now back down near the lows, or even nudging new intraday troughs. Gilts are close to the bottom of a 126.55-94 range compared to their previous 127.37 settlement price and the 3 month strip is flat to 5.5 ticks adrift vs -0.5 to 6 ticks below par at one stage. All eyes glued to breaking headlines and opinion on the ‘legal assurances’ as a gauge to how the 2nd meaningful vote might go, but the defining word if not final and definitive one looks down to AG Cox. More immediately, a raft of domestic data all at 9.30GMT, but unlikely to garner much attention in the circumstances.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Tod’s (TOD IM) – CFO says 2019 is considered a year of transition in terms of profitability, and will be satisfied with flat or slight increase in profits. Co. has no plans to reinvest EUR 156mln from sale of Tokyo property to bur further Tokyo property. Co. proposes a dividend of EUR 1.00 vs. Prev. EUR 1.40. FY net income EUR 47.1mln vs. Exp. EUR 53mln. FY EBITDA EUR 118.3mln vs. Exp. EUR 125mln.(newswires)

G4S (G4S LN) – FY underlying revenue GBP 7.289bln vs. Prev. GBP 7.213bln. Final dividend of 6.11 pence per share. Co. state they are on track to deliver GBP 90-100mln of cost savings by 2020 to support investment and margin improvement. Co. state that they have a positive outlook for 2019. Co. add that they are taking steps to enable the commencement of separation of global cash solutions division in second half of year. (Newswires)

Interserve (IRV LN) – Co. confirms that it has been in discussion with Coltrane Asset Management to secure their support regarding a restructuring plan ahead of a shareholder vote on Friday. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – EU regulators are said to have the most concern over execution risks of a merger between the Co. and Commerzbank (CBK GY) and if the deal failed issues would come up. (FT)

Fresenius Medical Care (FME GY) – Co. are to implement a share buyback of up to 6mln ordinary shares, which will be repurchased at a total price of up to EUR 330mln. Corresponds to around 1.6% of Co’s share capital. (Newswires)

Auto Names – Alphabets (GOOGL) self-driving car division Waymo is reportedly seeking financing from outside investors which includes European automakers such as Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) and Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM). (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – Co., Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors say they are to create a new alliance operating board, Co’s Chairman Senard will head the board; but will not seek to become Nissan Chairman. Will drive operational cooperation among companies. (Newswires)

Enagas (ENG SM) – Co. are to pay, as part of a consortium, USD 590mln for a 10.93% indirect ownership interest in Tallgrass Energy. Co. sees average annual dividend for 2019-23 period from Tallgrass of around EUR 60mln. (Newswires)

UBS (UBSG SW) – FINMA are in contact with the Co. regarding a 2014 loan to Papua New Guinea. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – FDA has approved the Co’s and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals drug Dupixent for use with patients aged 12-17. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region took impetus from the M&A inspired tech-led rally on Wall St
  • UK PM May has secured “legally binding” changes to her Withdrawal Agreement, however, she did not get the power to unilaterally exit the backstop, nor did she get a time limit placed on it
  • European Commission President Juncker said that the legal add-on to the Brexit deal stresses the temporary nature of the backstop and he warned if the deal is voted down, there was “no third chance”
  • In FX markets, GBP/USD remained in the limelight after PM May secured legally-binding assurances from the EU, whilst EUR/GBP was briefly dragged below 0.8500
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swedish inflation, UK GDP estimate, US inflation, API crude inventories, UK House of Commons to vote on PM May’s Brexit deal

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region took impetus from the M&A inspired tech-led rally on Wall St and with sentiment also underpinned on Brexit related optimism after UK PM May’s last-ditch effort to reach an agreement with the EU resulted in legally binding changes that is said to strengthen and improve the withdrawal agreement. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was led higher by the energy sector following recent strength in oil prices but with gains eventually pared by weakness in gold miners and financials, while the Nikkei 225 (+1.9%) outperformed with the JPY-risk dynamic in full swing. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.8%) conformed to the heightened risk appetite and tech-kindled momentum, while China’s tax commissioner reiterated to enact significant tax cuts and there were also reports that top US and China trade negotiation officials discussed key issues and set the next steps in working arrangements over the phone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially subdued with demand sapped as focus was centred on riskier assets and with participants tentative ahead of a 5yr JGB auction, although prices then found mild support on return from the lunch break and after the auction results printed relatively inline with the previous. 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7128 (Prev. 6.7202)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He conducted a phone call with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which they discussed key issues regarding ongoing trade talks and set the next steps in working arrangements. (Xinhua) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM May secured legally binding changes that strengthen and improve the withdrawal agreement, according to UK cabinet office minister Lidington who added that the whole UK cabinet approves of Brexit deal improvements. Lidington announced to lay a joint legally binding instrument and joint statement in parliament which provides confirmation EU cannot try to trap the UK in the backstop and if EU were to act with that intention, the UK could use it as basis for formal dispute through independent arbitration, while the joint statement said EU and UK commit to finding alternative arrangements to the backstop by 2020. However, PM May did not get the power to unilaterally exit the backstop, nor did she get a time limit placed on it. (Newswires)

European Commission President Juncker told reporters that the legal add-on to the Brexit deal which stresses the temporary nature of the backstop, complements the withdrawal agreement without reopening it. Juncker also warned if her deal is voted down, there was “no third chance”. Juncker said the EU wants the UK to exit an orderly way and we have a deal which does that. Juncker also commented there will be no new negotiations on Brexit and that it is this deal or Brexit may not happen at all, while he added that the UK must leave by May 23rd or hold elections for EU lawmakers. (Newswires/Guardian)

UK PM May said the UK will make a unilateral declaration that there will be nothing to stop UK from leaving backstop if talks break down and that we have secured what parliament has asked for regarding the backstop, while PM May added she stands by what Brexit deal achieves for Britain and that it sets us on course towards a good future relationship with the EU. Furthermore, the Times reported that PM May is understood to have discussed the possibility of extending Article 50 with EU’s Juncker. (Newswires/Times)

ERG's Rees Mogg said it was too early to say if this is enough but it’s a move in right direction, while ERG's Baker suggested it was not the first time the UK government has had to put a very good gloss on something which falls short of what was expected. Elsewhere, UK MP Collins said he will be voting against the government's motion on EU withdrawal and the DUP said it will study the detail of the latest EU-UK agreement, while UK opposition Labour Party Leader Corbyn said PM May's negotiations have failed and agreement with EU does not contain changes PM May promised parliament. (Newswires/BBC)

BBC Newsnight political editor tweeted 'Leading Brexiteer tells me: PM’s agreement with EU tonight just about looks OK. All down to Geoffrey Cox. If can provide robust legal advice that the UK can get out of the NI backstop, then this should go through'. (Twitter)

EU is said to be preparing for a delay to Brexit of at least a year, according to senior officials. (Times)

                                                                                                    

FX

In FX markets, GBP/USD remained in the limelight after PM May secured legally-binding assurances from the EU regarding the Northern Ireland backstop. The currency had already been advancing the prior day to reclaim the 1.3000 handle and move back above its 200DMA with the gains later exacerbated on hopes as PM May travelled to Strasbourg for 11th hour talks with the EU. The news of an agreement then fuelled a rally to within a whisker of the 1.3300 level although GBP/USD has since pulled back from its highs, as some remained pessimistic considering the existing wording of the Withdrawal Agreement which was said to be unchanged with the EU just offering legal assurances to back it up. Furthermore, ERG’s Baker suggested the agreement fell short of what was expected and Labour Leader Corbyn also deemed the negotiations as a failure with PM May not delivering what she promised parliament, while focus shifts to Attorney General Cox’s legal advice on whether the UK could be trapped forever in the backstop which is seen to likely influence the outcome of tonight’s vote and with CBA warning a potential 8% drop in the currency if the deal gets rejected. The breakthrough initially dragged EUR/GBP to below the 0.8500 level where it eventually found support, while the greenback was the main fallout from the GBP strength in which the DXY briefly gave up the 97.00 level to the benefit of its major counterparts. Elsewhere, antipodeans are firmer but with upside capped in AUD/USD after NAB Business Confidence and Home Loans added to Australia’s recent cold streak of data releases, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were elevated as risk sentiment spurred outflows from Japan’s haven currency. 

Australian NAB Business Confidence Feb 2 (Prev. 4). (Newswires) 

Australian NAB Business Conditions Feb 4 (Prev. 7) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were marginally higher amid the heightened risk appetite in which WTI crude futures reclaimed the USD 57.00/bbl in a continuation of its recent rebound and after OPEC reiterates to maintain cuts and reduce global inventories. Elsewhere, gold was also supported overnight but with the advances only marginal as the lack of safe-haven demand counterbalanced the effects of a weaker greenback, while copper outperformed on the firm risk sentiment.

OPEC official said OPEC will maintain cuts to reduce global inventories and will talk about demand and supply balance, while the official added OPEC will continue cutting production and wants to see commercial stocks down. Furthermore, there were also comments by OPEC Secretary General Barkindo that the oil market rebalancing continues to be a work in progress and supply adjustments will continue this year. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is to withdraw all remaining diplomatic staff from Venezuela this week. (Newswires)

US

The upbeat risk sentiment resulted to slight steepening in the Treasury curve (though 2s5s and 2s10s were a touch narrower). Analysts cited Powell’s positive comments on Friday (economy healthy), which contributed to some of the downside, though the main catalyst was likely equities bouncing back despite heavyweight Boeing trading red (see stock specifics). The Treasury sold new 3-year notes today at the lowest yield in a year; but although cover was in line with recent averages, the auction tailed by 0.4bps (average over the last six was 0.2bps tail). There wasn’t too much to take from the internals; indirect takedown rebounded on the month to the highest since December. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4 ticks lower at 122-20+.
